turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Bronze and brass ornamental work.
turn.1: What are some examples of bronze and brass ornamental work?
turn.2: The finest of all such boxes, the Firconi "cista" in the Villa Giulia at Rome, bears the signature of a Roman artist.
turn.3: What time period did these pieces originate?
turn.4: These belong to the 4th and 3rd centuries BC.
turn.5: Did they have any other uses?
turn.6: Greek mirrors of the same period are seldom engraved; the disk is usually contained in a flat box which has a "repoussé" design on its lid.
turn.7: What types of designs were popular?
turn.8: Hellenistic and Graeco-Roman forms are more conventional, and the new motives that belong to these periods are mostly floral.
turn.9: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.10: Busts and masks are the usual handle-plaques and spouts; heads and limbs of various animals are allotted certain decorative functions, as for instance the spirited mules' heads mentioned by Juvenal, which formed the elbow-rests of dining couches.
turn.11: What other materials were used to make these pieces?
turn.12: These structural pieces are frequently inlaid with silver and niello.
